ity. It is also common to rule out a test of personhood if we cannot knowwhen
the test is passed. For example, many people reject ensoulment as a criterion of
personhood, because they see no way to tell when, if ever, a fetus has a soul.
And tests of personhood are also often rejected if they depend on factors that
are extraneous. Conservatives often argue that viability cannot be a test of per-
sonhood, because the point when a fetus can survive outside the womb de-
